related_acts: Schedule to the Commercial Arbitration Act
paragraphs:
[1]
Jerome, A.C.J.
: These motions concerning the posting of security for the release of the vessel "Hebron Sea" came on for hearing at Toronto, Ontario on April 18, 1994.

[2]
By statement of claim filed March 31, 1994, the plaintiff (PIL) commenced an action against the defendant Secunda Marine Services Ltd. (Secunda), for breach of a contract pursuant to which the plaintiff was to carry out certain construction, repairs, equipping and conversion of the vessel. The plaintiff alleges that the defendants breached the terms of the contract as a result of which the plaintiff sustained damages in the amount of $1,075,000. The plaintiff claims an order requiring the defendants to submit to arbitration or, in the alternative, damages.

[3]
The plaintiff, pursuant to a warrant issued April 5, 1994, arrested the vessel which was lying at its shipyard in Pictou, Nova Scotia. On April 8, 1994, as a result of an application filed by Secunda in the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 43.05, Mr. Justice Saunders ordered PIL to deliver up the "Hebron Sea" to Secunda upon payment into court of $710,227.72 by Secunda. On April 13, 1994 both parties filed notices of motion in this court returnable April 18th. The defendants seek an order releasing the vessel, the "Hebron Sea" without provision of security and payment into court by the plaintiff of security for the defendants' claims in connection with the arbitration proceeding. The plaintiff seeks an order referring the parties to arbitration pursuant to Article 8 of the
Commercial Arbitration Code
, being the Schedule to the
Commercial Arbitration Act
, R.S.C. 1985, c. 17 (2nd supplement) as amended.

[4]
It is only in very rare cases that in the absence of consent, the court will order the release of an arrested vessel without the posting of security even where the parties are pursuing arbitration of the dispute. The defendants argue that clause 8 of the contract between the parties, which provides that the vessel shall be free from all liens, charges and encumbrances, except only the contractor's liens for any unpaid portion of the contract price applicable to the actual progress, precludes the plaintiff from arresting and seeking security for the release of the vessel. An arrest pursuant to ss. 22(2)(n) and 43(3) of the
Federal Court Act
does not create an encumbrance as contemplated by this paragraph. Rather, it is a procedural remedy which follows an action in rem. However, the amount of security sought by the plaintiff, being $1.5 million, is excessive given the amount of its claim. I am therefore, only prepared to order that the defendants post security in the amount of $800,000, $710,000 of which is to be co-extensive with the security to be posted in the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia pursuant to the order of Mr. Justice Saunders.

[5]
The defendants argue that an order should issue requiring the plaintiff to provide security for its claims in arbitration. Having reviewed the pleadings filed to date and the affidavits filed on behalf of the defendants on this motion, I am unable to identify any claims advanced by the defendants against the plaintiff which would justify the issuance of an order requiring the posting of security for the cost of the alleged deficiencies. Furthermore, in a proceeding such as this I am not convinced that the court should exercise its discretion to issue what amounts to a
Mareva
injunction where the specifics of the claims have not been sufficiently identified and there is no indication that the party against whom the order is to be made intends to remove assets for the purpose of defeating the claims. Therefore, no order for security will issue against the plaintiff.

[6]
Both parties have indicated that they wish to proceed to arbitration. Accordingly, pursuant to Article 8 of the
Commercial Arbitration Code
, being the Schedule to the
Commercial Arbitration Act
, R.S.C. 1985, c. 17 (2nd supplement) the parties are referred to arbitration. Costs in the cause.
Order accordingly.
Editor: Gary W. McLaughlin/dlr
[End of document]

statutes: Commercial Arbitration Code, being the Schedule to the Commercial Arbitration Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. 17 (2nd supplement)
legal_issues: The circumstances under which a court may release an arrested vessel without requiring security, even when arbitration is pending.
Whether a contractual clause prohibiting liens and encumbrances precludes the arrest of a vessel as a procedural remedy.
The appropriate amount of security to be posted for the release of an arrested vessel, considering the amount of the claim.
Whether to compel a party to provide security for potential counterclaims in arbitration, absent a clear demonstration of valid claims and risk of asset dissipation.
The court's authority to order security for costs in the context of arbitration where claims are not fully defined.
factual_background: PIL initiated a claim against Secunda Marine Services Ltd. for breach of contract related to construction, repairs, equipping, and conversion of the vessel "Hebron Sea".
PIL claimed damages of $1,075,000 and requested either arbitration or monetary damages.
PIL arrested the "Hebron Sea" while it was at a shipyard in Pictou, Nova Scotia.
Secunda applied to the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia, which ordered PIL to release the vessel upon Secunda’s payment of $710,227.72 into court.
Both parties filed motions in court on April 13, 1994: Secunda sought release of the vessel without security, and PIL sought an order for arbitration.
Secunda argued a clause in the contract precluded PIL from arresting the vessel.
Both parties indicated a willingness to proceed to arbitration.

Applicants: The defendants breached the contract for construction, repairs, equipping and conversion of the vessel, resulting in damages of $1,075,000.
An order should be made referring the parties to arbitration pursuant to Article 8 of the Commercial Arbitration Code.
The amount of security sought ($1.5 million) is reasonable to secure the release of the vessel.
Respondents: Clause 8 of the contract, stating the vessel shall be free from liens and encumbrances (except contractor's liens for unpaid work), precludes the plaintiff from arresting the vessel and seeking security for its release.
An arrest under ss. 22(2)(n) and 43(3) of the Federal Court Act does not create an encumbrance as contemplated by clause 8, but is a procedural remedy.
The plaintiff should provide security for the respondents' claims in the arbitration proceeding.
The amount of security sought by the plaintiff ($1.5 million) is excessive given the amount of the plaintiff's claim.

court_analysis: The court determined that releasing the arrested vessel without security was inappropriate despite the parties' intent to arbitrate, finding such releases are only granted in rare circumstances without consent.

The court rejected the defendant’s argument that a contractual clause preventing liens and encumbrances precluded the plaintiff’s arrest of the vessel, clarifying that an arrest under the Federal Court Act is a procedural remedy *in rem* and does not create an encumbrance as contemplated by the contract.

The court found the plaintiff’s requested security amount of $1.5 million to be excessive in relation to the $1,075,000 claim and reduced it to $800,000, with $710,000 to align with existing security posted in the Nova Scotia Supreme Court.

The court denied the defendant’s request for the plaintiff to post security for the arbitration, finding no sufficiently identified counterclaims had been made and no evidence suggested the plaintiff intended to dissipate assets to avoid potential liabilities; the court was unwilling to grant a Mareva-like injunction under these circumstances.
The court ordered the parties to proceed to arbitration as per Article 8 of the Commercial Arbitration Code, acknowledging both parties’ desire to do so.
final_outcome: The defendants are to post security in the amount of $800,000, $710,000 of which is to be co-extensive with the security to be posted in the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia.
The application for an order requiring the plaintiff to provide security for its claims in arbitration was denied.
The parties are referred to arbitration pursuant to Article 8 of the Commercial Arbitration Code.
Costs in the cause are awarded.
